channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Britain Asks if Tone of ‘Brexit’ Campaign Made Violence Inevitable
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, the leader of the U.K. Independence Party, released a new poster for the campaign for Britain to leave the European Union on Thursday.
item.description: The killing of Jo Cox, a politician in favor of remaining in the European Union, has put a focus on the anti-immigrant tactics some in the “Leave” campaign have employed.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Choosing ‘Brexit’ Could Leave the Kingdom Less United
item.media:description: An abandoned customs post on Ireland’s side of the border with Northern Ireland. This frontier could become a lot more visible if Britain votes next week to leave the European Union while Ireland remains.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: A vote by Britain to leave the European Union could create pressure for Scottish independence and harden the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Jo Cox, Member of British Parliament, Is Killed in Attack
item.media:description: A vigil in Parliament Square in London for Jo Cox, the member of Parliament who was killed in northern England on Thursday.
item.description: Ms. Cox, a Labour lawmaker representing Batley and Spen in northern England, died after being shot outside a library in her district.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and PAULINE BOCK

item.title: Iraqi Forces Enter Falluja, Encountering Little Fight From ISIS
item.media:description: Iraqis, after fleeing the violence in Falluja, reached the outskirts of Baghdad on Thursday. The latest wave of civilians has left aid agencies struggling to care for them.
item.description: Counterterrorism forces raised the Iraqi flag over the city’s main government building, according to officers and news reports on state television.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: 51 U.S. Diplomats Urge Strikes Against Assad in Syria
item.media:description: Smoke and flames rose after what fighters of the Syrian Democratic Forces said were American-led airstrikes on the mills of Manbij where Islamic State militants are positioned, in Aleppo, Syria, on Thursday.
item.description: An internal memo, critical of Obama administration policy, says military action is necessary to stop violations of a cease-fire in the civil war.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: EgyptAir 804 Flight Data Recorder Is Found, Egyptian Investigators Say
item.description: The announcement came one day after they said they had found the cockpit voice recorder of the doomed plane, which crashed on May 19.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Desperation Rising at Home, Africans Increasingly Turn to Risky Seas
item.media:description: Samba Thiam, 23, came to Dakar, Senegal, from his village nearly 400 miles away to look for work. He and more than a dozen other men now live in a concrete house in a development created in the 1970s to shelter the poor.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: More than 1,300 migrants have died trying to cross the Mediterranean in boats from North Africa in the last few weeks alone.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Judge in Kenya Upholds Use of Anal Exams for Men Suspected of Being Gay
item.media:description: Kenyan supporters of gay rights protesting proposed anti-gay legislation in Uganda in 2014.
item.description: The court denied a petition to overturn the use of mandatory anal exams in Kenya, where homosexual sex can lead to an arrest.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Lethal Government Force Brings Ethiopian Region to Fearful Standstill
item.media:description: People mourned the death of Dinka Chala, who was killed by Ethiopian security forces, in December in the Oromia region. He was accused of protesting, but his family said he was not involved.
item.description: Since protests erupted in the Oromia region seven months ago, more than 400 people, almost all civilians, have died, according to a Human Rights Watch report.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: 194 Held in Bangladesh Mass Arrests May Have Militant Ties, Police Say
item.media:description: Activists in Dhaka, Bangladesh, held portraits on Wednesday of people who were among those killed in recent years in attacks claimed by Islamist militants.
item.description: The police came under sharp criticism from human rights activists for arresting more than 11,000 people in response to a campaign of killings by Islamist militants.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: 11 Sentenced to Life for Muslim Killings During Gujarat Riots in India
item.description: The men were convicted of participating in a mob that set fire to a housing complex where scores of Muslims were taking refuge, killing 69 people inside.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Publisher in Exile Gets the Big Scoops on China’s Elite
item.media:description: Ho Pin, who runs a Chinese-language publishing company, in Queens in February. Living in the United States is his strategy for staying out of the clutches of China’s police if his publications offend the Communist Party.
item.media:credit: Caitlin Ochs for The New York Times
item.description: While a crackdown stifles other freewheeling publishers, Ho Pin offers uncensored coverage from his Long Island office, beyond Beijing’s reach.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Premier of Ukraine Urges Europe Not to Ease Russia Sanctions
item.media:description: Soldiers from the First Mechanized Battalion, 14th Mechanized Brigade of the Ukrainian Army in February at a front-line position in Marinka, Ukraine.
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.description: Remarks by Prime Minister Volodymyr B. Groysman came as European officials appeared to make an effort to temper the worst estrangement in relations with Russia since the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Vladimir Putin Says Russian Athletes’ Ban From Olympics Is Politically Motivated
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at an economic forum in St. Petersburg on Friday. He said that doping in sports was a global problem and that Russian athletes had been unfairly singled out.
item.description: After his country’s track and field team was barred from competing at this summer’s Olympics in Brazil, Mr. Putin claimed the move was part of an “anti-Russia policy” by the West.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Trilobites: 12,000 Years Ago, Humans and Climate Change Made a Deadly Team
item.media:description: An illustration from the 19th century of a giant ground sloth, which was among the many megafaunal species that went extinct in Patagonia during a rapid warming phase that followed the Antarctic Cold Reversal. Researchers found that the combination of human encroachment with the warming contributed to the extinctions.
item.description: By dating bones and teeth from megafauna found in South America, researchers found that prehistoric extinctions were tied to warming and the presence of humans.
item.dc:creator: TATIANA SCHLOSSBERG

item.title: Syrian Baby Born With Deformities Gets Spanish O.K. to Come for Surgery
item.description: Sham Aldaher, who was born in Jordan in July, has been offered treatment in Barcelona, but her family struggled to get a visa.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Says It Won’t Take E.U. Money for Refugees
item.media:description: A migrant family sat on train tracks outside their tent in a refugee camp in Idomeni, Greece, in March. Tens of thousands of migrants are stranded in such camps in Greece.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: One of Europe’s biggest charities said Friday it is turning its back on millions of dollars to protest the bloc’s “shameful deterrence policies” on migrants.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Sinosphere: 3 Others Detained in China Over Liquor Commemorating Tiananmen Killings
item.media:description: A man stood before a line of tanks near Tiananmen Square in Beijing in June 1989. Liquor bottles with labels riffing on that protest began circulating on WeChat in May.
item.description: The bottles bore the image of a lone man blocking a line of tanks, a reference to an iconic figure of resistance to the deadly 1989 military crackdown.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Turkey Bans Gay Pride Parade in Istanbul After Threats of Violence
item.media:description: Participants took part in a lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender pride march in Istanbul last year.
item.media:credit: Isa Terli/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: The governor of Istanbul has banned gay, lesbian and transgender individuals from holding pride parades at their usual venue, citing security concerns.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: A Front-Row Seat to Germany’s Long Reckoning With Its Past
item.description: After the sentencing of Reinhold Hanning, who may be the last former Nazi sentenced for war crimes, reflections on how Germany has addressed its history.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Bookseller’s Account of Abduction Rekindles Fear of Lost Rights in Hong Kong
item.description: The detention of Lam Wing-kee on the mainland has many worried that harsh Chinese justice, or lawlessness, is seeping into the city.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: 2 Chinese Activists Sentenced to Over 10 Years on Subversion Charges
item.media:description: People last year protesting the detention of Chinese activists who support Hong Kong’s Umbrella Movement, including Lu Gengsong and Chen Shuqing, in Hong Kong.
item.description: Lu Gengsong and Chen Shuqing were convicted for publishing pro-democracy essays on overseas websites and promoting the banned China Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Thomas Mair, Suspect in Jo Cox Killing, Had History of Neo-Nazi Ties and Mental Illness
item.media:description: Police officers searched near where Ms. Cox was shot a day earlier in Birtsall, England, on Friday.
item.description: The British police say they believe Mr. Mair targeted Ms. Cox, a 41-year-old Member of Parliament and a Labour Party member.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Sinosphere: American Kills Himself in Taiwan Court After 4-Year Drug Sentence
item.description: The man, Tyrel Martin Marhanka, convicted of growing marijuana for personal use, slashed his throat with scissors at his sentencing, court officials said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Stay or Go: Why the ‘Brexit’ Warnings Don’t Seem to Be Working in Britain
item.media:description: Pro-Brexit flags flew from a fishing boat moored in Ramsgate, England, this week.
item.media:credit: Chris J Ratcliffe/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Gloomy forecasts of pain from a breakup have not resonated with British voters amid a generally sunny economy.
item.dc:creator: PETER EAVIS

item.title: Brazil’s Tourism Minister Resigns Amid Corruption Accusations
item.description: The minister, Henrique Alves, is the third minister to step down amid a sweeping graft investigation of the state oil company Petrobras.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Prime Minister of Croatia Is Ousted by the Party That Backed Him
item.media:description: Prime Minister Tihomir Oreskovic of Croatia, right, looked on as members of Parliament voted to oust him on Thursday in Zagreb.
item.media:credit: Stipe Mayic/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: The move against Prime Minister Tihomir Oreskovic brought down the Croatian government and ended a brief union between reformers and a nationalist right-wing party.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH OROVIC

item.title: In Race for Mayor of Rome, a Prize and a New Face for the Five Star Movement
item.media:description: Virginia Raggi, a lawyer and municipal councilor in Rome. She appears poised to become Rome’s mayor in a runoff election on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Born as a voice of anti-establishment protest in Italy, the movement is poised to win the city’s mayoral runoff on Sunday behind Virginia Raggi, a relative newcomer.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: The Interpreter: When a Phrase Takes On New Meaning: ‘Radical Islam,’ Explained
item.media:description: President Obama, who met on Tuesday with the National Security Council, says the focus on the “radical Islam” phrase is “a political distraction.”
item.description: A dispute between President Obama and Donald Trump in the aftermath of the Orlando massacre can be traced to the rise of the Islamic State, scholars say.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: France Arrests More Than 300 in Euro Soccer Tournament’s First Week
item.media:description: A man was arrested last week as soccer fans clashed in Marseille, France.
item.description: Fan violence has marred the start of the Euro 2016 tournament and heightened security concerns in a country already under high alert.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Fighting ISIS With an Algorithm, Physicists Try to Predict Attacks
item.media:description: An explosion in Kobani, Syria, during fighting between Kurdish and Islamic State fighters in October 2014. Researchers found a spike in the formation of small online groups connected to the Islamic State before the attack began in September of that year.
item.description: A new mathematical model aims to track the activity of Islamic State sympathizers online and determine when groups will turn from talk to action.
item.dc:creator: PAM BELLUCK
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Defying China, Hong Kong Bookseller Describes Detention
item.description: Lam Wing-kee, whose Hong Kong bookstore sold gossipy books about China’s leadership, says he was detained at the border by captors who wanted customers’ details.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG, MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Shifting Attention to Mediterranean, NATO Fights Internal Dissent
item.media:description: British paratroopers jumped from a C-130 Hercules plane during an alliance training exercise near Torun, Poland, this month.
item.description: Beyond confronting Russia in the east, the alliance is facing an array of challenges on its southern flank, including terrorism and uncontrolled migration.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Christo’s Newest Project: Walking on Water
item.media:description: A new installation by the artist Christo, “The Floating Piers,” consists of temporary bridges spanning Italy’s Lake Iseo.
item.description: For 16 days, “The Floating Piers,” a saffron-colored walkway, will connect two small islands in a lake in Northern Italy to the mainland.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Palestinian Killed by Israeli Soldier Posed No Danger, Commander Testifies
item.media:description: The body of Abdel Fattah al-Sharif after he was killed by an Israeli soldier in the West Bank city of Hebron in March.
item.description: The commander said the Palestinian, who had already been shot and wounded after stabbing another soldier, was no longer a threat when Sgt. Elor Azaria shot him in the head.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ

item.title: As Russian Hackers Probe, NATO Has No Clear Cyberwar Strategy
item.media:description: The Dutch warship Johan De Witt during NATO exercises off southern Finland this month. The maneuvers included an amphibious landing, the first by alliance forces in Finnish territory.
item.description: When it comes to deterring the low-level attacks that flow through European computer networks every week, NATO commanders do not seem prepared to take aggressive countermeasures.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Judge Denies Reza Zarrab’s Bail Request for Self-Financed House Arrest
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab, a gold trader facing trial in New York, in December 2013. Mr. Zarrab had offered to pay for his own detention while awaiting trial.
item.description: Mr. Zarrab, a gold trader from Turkey, had asked to be allowed to live in an apartment under 24-hour armed guard and GPS monitoring, all at his own expense.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: EgyptAir 804’s ‘Black Box’ Recovered in Mediterranean
item.description: The cockpit voice recorder from a flight that crashed as it flew from Paris to Cairo last month was damaged, investigators said.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF and NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Davao City Journal: Welcome to Davao, the Philippine Leader’s Town: ‘No Smoking, No Crime’
item.media:description: Children on a beach in Davao City, the Philippines, across from the resort island of Samal, where four people were kidnapped by Islamic rebels in September.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: President-elect Rodrigo Duterte’s strict policies may be a tough sell in much of the country. But in Davao City, where he was mayor, residents say they feel safe.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: ISIS Committed Genocide Against Yazidis in Syria and Iraq, U.N. Panel Says
item.media:description: Yazidis fleeing Sinjar, Iraq, in 2014 after forces loyal to the Islamic State took the town. Kurdish and Yazidi fighters retook it last fall.
item.description: A commission of inquiry found evidence of mass killings of members of the religious minority.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sinosphere: China Is Said to Rescind Invitation to Taiwan Children’s Choir
item.media:description: The Puzangalan Choir with the new president of Taiwan, Tsai Ing-wen, left, and vice president, Chen Chien-jen, at their inauguration in Taipei on May 20.
item.description: Organizers of an event in Guangdong Province canceled the invitation to the Puzangalan Choir after a performance at the presidential inauguration in Taiwan in May.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: European? British? These ‘Brexit’ Voters Identify as English
item.media:description: Residents of the Castle Point borough of Essex in England celebrated the queen’s 90th birthday this month. Castle Point is the most ethnically English part of the United Kingdom, with nearly 80 percent describing themselves as purely English, while 95 percent are white.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: In the debate over whether Britain should leave the European Union, a fierce sense of English identity could prove critical to the outcome.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Uber Rival’s $28 Billion Valuation Shows Size of China’s Ride-Sharing Market
item.media:description: A driver waits for a fare at a Didi Station in Shanghai. Didi and Uber have been locked in a spending war.
item.description: Didi Chuxing brought in $7.3 billion in its latest fund-raising round, giving it a valuation of almost half that of Uber, its main competitor in China.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Leaving Past Behind, Northern Ireland Unified Behind Its Team
item.media:description: Northern Ireland fans applauded their team after Sunday’s loss in the European Championships.
item.description: A boy who watched the biggest soccer match in his country’s history in 1982 is now the coach. He hopes to replicate the team’s success in the European Championships.
item.dc:creator: JAMES MONTAGUE

item.title: What in the World: A Magnet for Titanic Fans in an Unexpected Graveyard
item.media:description: The Fairview Lawn Cemetery in Halifax, Nova Scotia, on April 15, 2012, the 100th anniversary of the sinking of the Titanic.
item.description: Fairview Lawn Cemetery holds more victims of the world’s best-known shipwreck than any other place — including the grave of a certain J. Dawson.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: What in the World: Rise at 11? China’s Single Time Zone Means Keeping Odd Hours
item.description: Some days, the sun doesn’t come up until 10 a.m. in Urumqi, where clocks are set to Beijing time despite being 2,000 miles to the west.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: The Deeper Meaning of Mexico’s Giant Speed Bumps
item.media:description: A well-worn tope in Mexico City, scarred by the undercarriages of countless cars.
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: Suspension-killing wonders called topes, which crop up on highways and back streets alike, are a means of enforcing speed control and civility, and cannot be avoided.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Opinion: Drought Selfies and Drought Suicides
item.media:description: A boy from a rural village stricken by drought standing guard over his family’s water containers at a camp in Mumbai, India.
item.description: India's government cares little for the plight of the rural poor.
item.dc:creator: SONIA FALEIRO

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte: After Orlando
item.description: Donald Trump is assiduous about word choice.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Mr. Modi, Don't Patent Cow Urine
item.description: India’s innovative patent system has brought cheap generic drugs to millions. Now it’s under threat — because the Hindu right is obsessed with cows.
item.dc:creator: ACHAL PRABHALA and SUDHIR KRISHNASWAMY

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
